body.p: The arrow in the image above points to which organ?
Classified as a lymphoid organ, this organ traps antigens entering the body through the mouth and nasal cavity, where lymphocytes destroy the invading microorganisms.

response.feedback: Correct. The tonsils are masses of lymphoid tissues that form a ring at the back of the nose and mouth cavity where the pharynx connects.
Not quite. The adenoids work together with the tonsils to filter ingested and inhaled material.
Incorrect. The spleen is in the abdomen.
Incorrect. The thymus is near the organ you are asked to identify, but is located near the trachea.

part.hint: Some children who have lots of infections in their throat have to have these organs removed.

response.feedback: Correct. Fully developed white cells collect in the tonsils ready to defend the body against infectious and foreign microorganisms.
Incorrect. Bone marrow and the thymus are the primary lymphoid organs where lymphocytes develop.
This is not the best answer, although the tonsils do provide a first line of defense against pathogens entering the mouth and nasal cavity and consequently are subject to chronic infections.

part.hint: These organs are next after the most important organs, which develop the immune cells.

response.feedback: Correct. Lymphocytes are generated in the bone marrow and mature in the thymus. After these white blood cells fully develop, they circulate to the tonsils, spleen and other lymphoid organs.
